item.title: Ticket #24756 (Don't limit local autosave only to Posts) created
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description: There is some left-over code limiting the local autosave (in sessionStorage) only to Posts. This limitation should be removed making it run on all Add New* and Edit* screens where autosave.js is loaded or alternatively it should also run on Add New Page and Edit Page.

item.title: 24755.patch attached to Ticket #24755
item.dc:creator: azaozz

item.title: Ticket #24755 (Multiple copies of backup-post-in-browser-different message) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description: Actually multiple copies of the error message will be inserted if there are more than one <h2> at the top of the page. Can reproduce when there are 14 <h2>'s and only the first is visible. Not sure what could be adding them.

item.title: Ticket #24755 (Multiple copies of backup-post-in-browser-different message) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
Can't reproduce either. There is something weird going on at that site. The call to the function that displays the error message is hard-coded (see ​here and ​here). Not sure how it can run multiple times unless the actual autosave.js file is loaded multiple times.

Looking at the ​screencast there is a plugin (or several plugins) extending TinyMCE. May have something to do with this.

item.title: 24736.5.patch attached to Ticket #24736
item.dc:creator: adamsilverstein
item.description: use span instead of :after psuedo element for ie transform support; correct placement of tooltip in IE8 & RTL

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: adamsilverstein
item.description: note: in 24736.5.patch​ tooltips are missing in ie7. needs fixing

item.title: Ticket #24183 (MediaElement.js i18n issues) updated
item.dc:creator: SergeyBiryukov
item.description: Pull request was accepted. Once 2.12.1 is out, 24183.4.patch​ should be good to go.

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: adamsilverstein
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

The tooltip arrow thing is because of the transform, probably. The overflow is probably due to lack of support for border-box, so the border that makes the tick mark is causing it to equal more than 100%.

tried adding the correct ie 7/8 transform code, but apparently older ie doesn't support transforming psuedo elements.

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: adamsilverstein
item.description:
Replying to markjaquith:

The tooltip arrow thing is because of the transform, probably. The overflow is probably due to lack of support for border-box, so the border that makes the tick mark is causing it to equal more than 100%.

apparently ie 7 also has a hard time adding percentages up to 100%, it is apparently rounding up and adding pixels in the process. latest patch shifts to a right border and leaves off the last tickmark, fixing overflow for ie7 at least until you have a lot of revisions.

item.title: 24736.4.patch attached to Ticket #24736
item.dc:creator: adamsilverstein
item.description: switch to right borders for tickmarks, leave off last div, fixes some overflow issues for ie7; also removed >div:first-child selector, no longer needed, not supported in ie 7

At most, this message should show up once.

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: The tooltip arrow thing is because of the transform, probably. The overflow is probably due to lack of support for border-box, so the border that makes the tick mark is causing it to equal more than 100%.

item.title: Ticket #23292 (Media uploader loads full size image and slows down, please change to ...) updated
item.dc:creator: MDesigner0
item.description: Also, on the product listing page (Woocommerce), small versions of full-size images are shown. I'm not sure if that's specific to WooCommerce, or if it's the same as a standard post listing page.

item.title: Ticket #23292 (Media uploader loads full size image and slows down, please change to ...) updated
item.dc:creator: MDesigner0
item.description: Ah! Good to know. Hope 3.6 is out soon. If my wife's MacBook blows up from overheating, I'll never hear the end of it. ;)

item.title: Ticket #23292 (Media uploader loads full size image and slows down, please change to ...) updated
item.dc:creator: DrewAPicture
item.description:
Keywords changed

Rather than switching from one size to another (which doesn't provide any more flexibility than we already have), 23292.diff​ adds a filter to $attachment_url. More flexibility for different use cases.

For example, with the filter, something like this could be used: 

function filter_prepared_attachment_size( $url, $attachment ) {
	return wp_get_attachment_thumb_url( $attachment->ID );
}
add_filter( 'wp_prepare_attachment_url', 'filter_prepared_attachment_size', 10, 2 );

Replying to MDesigner0:

I hate to say it, but that patch does not work. Nor does the original ticket submitter's fix. Of course, I'm in 3.5.1, does that make a difference? That line of code is on 1333 for me, not 1604.

Patches here are against latest trunk which is currently 3.6 RC1.

item.title: Ticket #24754 ("Add Media" button loads up full-size images instead of true thumbnails) created
item.dc:creator: MDesigner0
item.description:
When clicking the "Add Media" button on a post, the images shown are full size images shrunk down using WIDTH/HEIGHT parameters. This results in high CPU load in the browser (and on some machines, making them overheat). Large images (10MB+) are needed for e-commerce sites, for example, where people want to zoom in and see extreme detail.

Please fix the Add Media window to show true thumbnails like the "Media Library" listing does. Thanks!

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Went with the overflow-y-in-JS route. Untested on IE.

item.title: 24736-combined.2.diff attached to Ticket #24736
item.dc:creator: markjaquith

item.title: Ticket #24736 (Revisions: IE compatibilty) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Combined the patches and removed the whitespace changes (at this point, we need to carefully consider changes, so let's make our patches as succinct as possible).

For the IE7 double scrollbar, we have two options: override the rule for IE7, or apply the fix using JS (which we can 100% count on, given that this is a JS app).

item.title: Ticket #24747 (Strict Standards errors on plugin search) updated
item.dc:creator: SergeyBiryukov
item.description: Keywords, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #24747 (Strict Standards errors on plugin search) updated
item.dc:creator: SergeyBiryukov
item.description:
Replying to DrewAPicture:

Cool. Is this is a PHP version-specific thing -- in other words -- how would one reproduce this?

I can reproduce in PHP 5.3 by setting error_reporting( E_ALL | E_STRICT ) in a mu-plugin.

In PHP 5.4, E_ALL includes E_STRICT, so just define('WP_DEBUG', true) in wp-config.php is enough.

As noted in comment:6, the message only appears for already installed plugins that don't have an update yet.

item.title: Ticket #24636 (WP_User has no method to access WP_User->data) updated

item.title: Ticket #24753 (Create Gallery Page Shows Wrong Selection) created
item.dc:creator: miqrogroove
item.description:
In 3.6 RC1:

  1. Click the Add Media button on the dashboard.
  2. Click one of the images on the Insert Media modal page.
  3. Click "Create Gallery".
  4. Click another image.

Expected behavior:

The two images in the selection should appear to be selected

Actual behavior:

There are two images in the selection at the bottom of the window, but only one image appears to be selected.

When clicking the other image, nothing happens. Only the images other than the one originally selected can be added to or removed from the gallery.

If you click the "Create a new gallery" button and then click "Add to Gallery", that first-selected image appears as an available image, as though it hasn't been added to the gallery already.

item.title: Ticket #24750 (Pagination control has disappeared for Users in Network Admin) updated
item.dc:creator: DrewAPicture
item.description:
Keywords, Version changed

wp_is_large_network() replaced get_blog_count() >= 10000 in 3.3 in [18871], so I'm not sure how it worked in *3.5.2 unless you

a) Had fewer than 10,000 users and you now don't b) Were using the wp_is_large_network filter to override the limitation and now aren't.

item.title: Ticket #24750 (Pagination control has disappeared for Users in Network Admin) updated
item.dc:creator: _ck_
item.description:
Oh duh, it's right in the 3.6 source, this is different from 3.5, very annoying

class-wp-ms-users-list-table.php 

// If the network is large and a search is not being performed, show only the latest users with no paging in order
// to avoid expensive count queries.

Worked fine for us in 3.5.3, will have to find a way to filter it back in.

The handlers in ajax-actions.php are split in three "areas": nopriv goes on top, followed by GET based handlers, followed by POST. This is to emphasis the difference as it's not immediately possible to figure out the request methods.

item.title: Ticket #24747 (Strict Standards errors on plugin search) created
item.dc:creator: DrewAPicture
item.description:
A user in Alpha/Beta ​reported getting Strict Standards errors doing a plugins search in Plugins > Add New. He first tried on Beta4, then again on RC1.

He's running PHP 5.4.7 (​full stack)

The error(s): 

"Strict Standards: Only variables should be passed by reference in C:\xampp\htdocs\wpbeta\wp-admin\includes\plugin-install.php on line 232"

His search string: 

http://localhost/wpbeta/wp-admin/plugin-install.php?tab=search&s=jonradio&plugin-search-input=Search+Plugins

Unfortunately, I don't have a PHP 5.4 install to try and reproduce it on, so maybe somebody else here can give it a go. I couldn't reproduce it on PHP 5.3.5, not sure what version @mordauk tested on.

item.dc:creator: mordauk
item.description:
I was looking through ajax-actions.php and noticed that wp_ajax_nopriv_heartbeat() is at the very top, while wp_ajax_heartbeat() is around line 2055.

For organization's sake, should the two functions be right next to each other?

I was first looking at wp_ajax_heartbeat() and didn't even realize there was a nopriv version until I did a search across the whole code base.

item.title: Ticket #24744 (Prevent user to activate a plugin network wide) created
item.dc:creator: wpfo
item.description:
So long we have not Settings API for network_wide activated plugins we need a way to prevent user to activate a plugin network wide.

Possible Solution: New header in Plugin File Header: Blog Blog - Boolean. Whether the plugin can only be activated per-site. If true - Action link 'Network Activate' will be hiden in Network Admin Plugins Table (problems are the bulk_actions in this approach).

We have now no way to prevent user to activate a plugin network wide. All 'plugin_action_links' Filters work only if a plugin is already activated. Or am I missing something?

Alternatively: we could have only one header for all activation modes e.g. Activation (or ActivationMode) - String

Network - plugin can only be activated network wide. Blog - plugin can only be activated per-site. Both - plugin can be activated network wide or per-site.

item.title: Ticket #24741 ("Quick Edit" button at "Comments" page doesn't work in slow connection) created
item.dc:creator: yongbae
item.description:
I found that "Quick Edit" button at "Comments" page does not correctly work when necessary JavaScript files are not yet fully loaded. I observe this problem in WordPress version 3.5.1.

I guess this problem happens when a user makes a clicks on “Quick Edit” button too soon before some external JavaScript for the feature get loaded. For this reason, It seems this bug would be more problematic when network connection is slow.

Here's the use case scenario by which you can reproduce the error:

  1. get log in WordPress site.
  1. click “Comments” button in left side menu in “Dashboard” page.
  1. click “Quick Edit” button. The error may occur at this moment -- even though you clicked, the input form may not show up, and my Firefox browser shows an uncaught exception:

item.title: Ticket #23684 (wp-admin CSS style conflicts with jQuery-UI breaking form elements in ...) updated
item.dc:creator: rfgoetz
item.description: Cc changed

item.title: Ticket #24740 (get_option does not respect WP_HOME, WP_SITEURL) created
item.dc:creator: daveagp
item.description:
I believe that get_option( $option ) in option.php should use WP_HOME and WP_SITEURL when they are available. This would involve adding 4 lines, 

   // about 10 lines into the function
        if ($option == 'home' && defined('WP_HOME'))
          return WP_HOME;
        if ($option == 'siteurl' && defined('WP_SITEURL'))
          return WP_SITEURL;
        if ( defined( 'WP_SETUP_CONFIG' ) ) // old code continues here

The reason this is really important is that there is no way to run a development site and a live site without doing hacks to core code or a pseudo-hacky drop-in replacement for db.php. See the discussion of line numbers in ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Running_a_Development_Copy_of_WordPress#Using_a_Drop-In for the details of why no non-hacky solution (such as filters) can work. But if we make this enhancement, then it is a simple matter of development sites defining these values within their wp-config.php which to me is the most satisfying and non-hacky approach.

Feedback is welcome on the exact best location within get_option to place this logic.

item.title: Ticket #24134 (Video Shortcode ignores sizes and aspect ratio) updated
item.dc:creator: DrewAPicture
item.description:
@wonderboymusic:

I just realized that we have no difficulty loading videos of all shapes and sizes in the attachment editing UI. Videos are loaded, displayed, and played with the proper dimensions no problem. This is the editing screen for the video I commented on above: ​http://cl.ly/image/2L173S3A141O

So if we're not trying to enforce responsiveness in the attachment UI, I'm not sure why we need to do it on the front-end. Let core handle outputting the content as intended and themes can handle the rest with fitVids or whatever.

item.title: Ticket #24183 (MediaElement.js i18n issues) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description: If we have to use it as-is, looks like will have to split mediaelement-and-player.js in two files. It has two parts: MediaElement.js at the top, MediaElementPlayer at the bottom. The translation needs to be between them to initialize properly.
